title: Series: Ballot Blocked Podcast
listingDescription: The history of voting rights isn’t solely a progressive or linear narrative. Passing legislation is only one step along the way to the ballot box. The laws must be enforced and that takes organizing and struggle. One hundred years after the 19th amendment barred states from denying the vote based on sex, the fight for social, economic, and political equality continues. Ballot Blocked explores how we got here and asks where we might be going next when it comes to voting rights.

listingImage.altText: A microphone and the text

title: Series: Fire at Point Reyes: Past, Present and Future
listingDescription: In this series, we'll dive into the past, present and future of fire in Point Reyes, by examining its impact on the seashore’s plants, animals and fungi. We’ll hear from scientists about how climate change, fire suppression, drought, and other human influences have changed the dynamics of wildfire in the West. And we’ll explore what the recovering seashore will look like in the coming months and years.

listingImage.altText: A firefighter in the corner of the frame as flames swirl around the base of a large tree.

title: Series: American Latino/a Heritage Theme Study
listingDescription: Latino history is American history. American Latinos and the Making of the United States: A Theme Study is a publication of the National Park System Advisory Board (NPSAB) for the National Park Service (NPS). Who is this theme study for? It's for students and teachers, for researchers, for preservation professionals, for local, state and federal government officials, and for the general public. In other words, it's for you.

listingImage.altText: Two women preparing for dia de los muertos.

title: Mammoth Cave Film Premieres at DC Festival
listingDescription: The film made its debut on March 18, 2021, in the DC Environmental Film Festival. The annual festival in the Nation’s Capital names itself the world’s premier showcase of environmentally themed films since 1993, and one of the leading annual cultural events in Washington, D.C. Mammoth Cave Biosphere Region was selected by jury to stream during the virtual festival.

listingImage.altText: movie poster of the Mammoth Cave Biosphere Region

title: “Wandering” Through Park Skies: How Peregrine Falcons Connect National Parks
listingDescription: Peregrine falcons live across the world and can be found throughout the United States. Learn how four national parks are connecting visitors to these remarkable birds.

listingImage.altText: A brown falcon sits on a green metal spike over water with a boat

title: Series: Curiosity Kit: Abby Kelley Foster
listingDescription: Curiosity Kits inspire exploration and learning of history through place. These multi-piece resources include articles that explore historic places and provide educational activities for life-long learners. This kit focuses on the life and work of Abby Kelley Foster, an abolitionist and women’s rights advocate. Use this series to learn about her work with the Underground Railroad and how she inspired suffragists like Elizabeth Cady Stanton and Susan B. Anthony.

listingImage.altText: Photo of a woman torso up.

title: Series: Curiosity Kit:
listingDescription: Curiosity Kits inspire exploration and learning of history through place. These multi-piece resources include articles that explore historic places and provide educational activities for life-long learners. This kit focuses on Katharine Lee Bates, author of what became the song “America the Beautiful.” Learn about some of the places associated with her life and work. You’ll also find activities and discussion questions for learners of all ages.

listingImage.altText: Katharine Lee Bates

title: Series: Curiosity Kit: African American Baseball
listingDescription: Curiosity Kits inspire exploration and learning of history through place. These multi-piece resources include articles that explore historic places and provide educational activities for life-long learners. This kit focuses on the history of Black baseball. Learn about places associated with famous African American players and use the activities to delve deeper into the topic.

listingImage.altText: Mural of baseball players lined up with field in foreground.

title: Series: Alaska Park Science - Volume 6 Issue 2: Crossing Boundaries in a Changing Environment
listingDescription: This issue covers the proceedings of the Central Alaska Park Science Symposium, held in Denali National Park. Topics include climate change monitoring, landscape and wildlife ecology, physical sciences, fisheries, subsistence, and using science as a tool for park management.

listingImage.altText: person in a canoe on a misty lake

title: Series: Amphibians and Reptiles in the Chihuahuan Desert
listingDescription: The American Southwest, including the Chihuahuan Desert Inventory and Monitoring (I&M) Network (CHDN), is well known for its abundance and diversity of reptiles. The area is less well known for its amphibians, but they are abundant in some habitats, particularly during favorable weather conditions.

listingImage.altText: Couch's spadefoot toad

title: Series: Buffalo National River Science Spotlights
listingDescription: Using Buffalo National River as a living laboratory, we can learn a lot about the natural world and its processes. These articles highlight the research and scientific endeavors that are happening now at Buffalo National River.

listingImage.altText: Students and scientists smile at us from the banks of Calf Creek

title: Series: NPS Mellon Humanities Fellowships to Advance the Education Mission Through Scholarship
listingDescription: For the enjoyment, education, and inspiration of this and future generations, the National Park Service draws upon the humanities to explore our shared history and its meanings. Humanities scholars study subjects like literature, philosophy, history, politics, religion, archaeology, and art to help us better understand and interpret the world. Investment from the Andrew W. Mellon Foundation has allowed NPS to host humanities scholars and share a greater diversity of American stories.

listingImage.altText: A group of people wearing hard hats

title: Series: The Emigrant Experience
listingDescription: Have you ever wondered what the experience was like for the emigrants who traveled west on the Great Platte River Road?

listingImage.altText: A man dressed in period clothing leans on a covered wagon.

title: Series: Curiosity Kit: Dr. Mabel Ping-Hua Lee
listingDescription: Curiosity Kits inspire exploration and learning of history through place. These multi-piece resources include articles that explore historic places and provide educational activities for life-long learners. This kit focuses on the life and work of Dr. Mabel Ping-Hua Lee, a suffragist. By the time she was 16, Lee was a known figure in New York’s suffrage movement. Learn more about her contributions to the movement.

listingImage.altText: Woman holding a bouquet of flowers.

tags: Asian American and Pacific Islander Heritage
Asian American and Pacific Islander History

title: Series: Curiosity Kit: Carrie Chapman Catt
listingDescription: Curiosity Kits inspire exploration and learning of history through place. These multi-piece resources include articles that explore historic places and provide educational activities for life-long learners. This kit focuses on Carrie Chapman Catt, a noted suffragist. Learn about some of the places associated with her life. You’ll also find activities and discussion questions for learners of all ages.

listingImage.altText: Carrie Chapman Catt

title: Series: Curiosity Kit: Lucy Stone
listingDescription: Curiosity Kits inspire exploration and learning of history through place. These multi-piece resources include articles that explore historic places and provide educational activities for life-long learners. This kit focuses on the life and work of Lucy Stone, a noted suffragist. You’ll also find activities and discussion questions for learners of all ages.

listingImage.altText: Lucy Stone

title: Series: Water Resources Monitoring in the Bighorn River near Fort Smith, Montana
listingDescription: The Greater Yellowstone Network monitors water quality and analyzes river discharge in the Bighorn River near Fort Smith, MT, each year. This sampling location in Bighorn Canyon National Recreation Area is just downstream of the Yellowtail Afterbay Dam. Water quality is relatively good at this location. We will update this site each year as new information is collected.

listingImage.altText: Two boats on the side of a blue river lined by green plants and a few trees

title: Series: The Road to Sacramento: Marching for Justice in the Fields
listingDescription: In the spring of 1966, a small group of California farmworkers and their supporters captured the attention of the nation. On March 17, nearly a hundred striking farmworkers, most of them Mexican American and Filipino, set out on foot from Delano, bound for the state capital in Sacramento, some 280 miles to the north. They marched to shine a light on the conditions in the fields and to demand for farmworkers the fundamental rights and freedoms to which other American workers were entitled.

listingImage.altText: Cesar Chavez stands with a map showing the route of the 1966 march.

title: Series: Curiosity Kit: Katharine Lee Bates
listingDescription: Curiosity Kits inspire exploration and learning of history through place. These multi-piece resources include articles that explore historic places and provide educational activities for life-long learners. This kit focuses on Katharine Lee Bates, author of what became the song “America the Beautiful.” Learn about some of the places associated with her life and work. You’ll also find activities and discussion questions for learners of all ages.

listingImage.altText: Katharine Lee Bates

title: Series: National History Day
listingDescription: National Historic Trails are full of topics waiting to be researched! From the Pony Express to the forced removal of American Indian tribes from their homelands, National Historic Trails tell stories of communication, movement, conflict, perseverance, and change.

listingImage.altText: A covered wagon sits in front of a large sandstone bluff.

tags: El Camino Real de Tierra Adentro

title: Series: Intermountain Park Science 2021
listingDescription: Integrating Research and Resource Management in Intermountain National Parks

listingImage.altText: Group of National Park Service staff and volunteers standing in front of a desert canyon.

title: Series: The Early Movements to Establish a Park in the Guadalupe Mountains
listingDescription: At the beginning of the Twentieth Century, to most Americans this remote corner of the Southwest was little more than windswept desert, a dry and brittle void on the national landscape. Until the year of the great stock market crash, there was no paved road connecting El Paso with Carlsbad. During this time, the surrounding region witnessed early attempts at oil and gas exploration, struggles with development, transportation, the impact of the Great Depression, and incipient tourism.

listingImage.altText: An automobile of the 1940s parked below a prominent peak.

title: Series: Teaching Justice
listingDescription: Identity. Diversity. Justice. Action. These learning activities engage students with the history of women's ongoing struggle for equality. Each lesson uses an item from the National Woman's Party collection or an aspect of the story of suffrage to make connections to broad questions of equity and the work of social change using anti-bias objectives from the Learning for Justice framework.

listingImage.altText: A word cloud at Belmont-Paul with the question

title: Series: What Does the Lincoln Memorial Mean to Me?
listingDescription: These learning activities engage middle and high school students with the history and meaning of the Lincoln Memorial. Each lesson focuses on a different aspect of the Lincoln Memorial dedication in 1922 and used primary sources to make connections between the intended purpose and the actual meaning of the memorial.

listingImage.altText: Lincoln Memorial Dedication

title: Series: Salem's Polish Community
listingDescription: With support from the National Park Service's Ethnography Program, researchers interviewed community members about their memories of the neighborhood, studied materials in archives, museums, and library collections, and pieced together an ethnohistorical account of Polish Salem from the 1870s to the present day. The information on these pages is excerpted the final report from the project, "In the Heart of Polish Salem: An Ethnohistorical Study of St. Joseph Hall and Its Neighborhood."

listingImage.altText: Black and white photo of three girls dressed in costumes.

title: Series: Park Paleontology News - Vol. 13, No. 2, Fall 2021
listingDescription:
All across the park system, scientists, rangers, and interpreters are engaged in the important work of studying, protecting, and sharing our rich fossil heritage. Park Paleontology news provides a close up look at the important work of caring for these irreplaceable resources.
  • Contribute to Park Paleontology News by contacting the newsletter editor
  • Learn more about Fossils & Paleontology
  • Celebrate National Fossil Day with events across the nation

listingImage.altText: fossil skull on display outdoors

title: Series: Pacific Ocean Education Team (POET) Newsletters
listingDescription: From 2009 to 2015, the Pacific Ocean Education Team published a series of short newsletters about the health of the ocean at various National Park Service sites in and around the Pacific Ocean. Topics covered included the 2010 tsunami, marine debris, sea star wasting disease, ocean acidification, and more.

listingImage.altText: Ocean waves wash in from the right onto a forested and rocky shoreline.

title: Series: Prehistoric Life of Tule Springs
listingDescription: Tule Springs Fossil Beds National Monument preserves thousands of Pleistocene (Ice Age) fossils that help tell the story of an ever-changing ecosystem. These fossils were preserved within expanding and contracting wetlands between 100,000-12,500 years ago. Many of the Pleistocene animals of Tule Springs are still alive today, including the coyote (Canis latrans), jackrabbit (Lepus sp.), and aquatic snails. Some animals went extinct, disappearing from North America entirely.

listingImage.altText: illustration of two ancient bison

title: Series: Curiosity Kit: Women Labor Activists in Chicago
listingDescription: Curiosity Kits inspire exploration and learning of history through place. These multi-piece resources include articles that explore historic places and provide educational activities for life-long learners. This kit focuses on the work of labor activists in Chicago and their efforts to organize and fight for better working conditions.

listingImage.altText: Poster of women activists.

title: Series: Curiosity Kit: American Aviation History
listingDescription: Curiosity Kits inspire exploration and learning of history through place. These multi-piece resources include articles that explore historic places and provide educational activities for life-long learners. This kit focuses on the history of American aviation with a focus on the contributions of women and African Americans.

listingImage.altText: Photo of Bessie Coleman.

title: Series: Archeology at Antietam- The Effect of Battle on an Agrarian Landscape
listingDescription: In the 1990s, the National Park Service and URS Greiner, Inc., conducted a survey to locate, identify, and inventory archeological sites within Antietam National Battlefield. This series is on research at three sites within the park — the Mary Locher/Alfred Poffenberger cabin, the North Woods, and the Mumma Farm — and presents a brief introduction to some of the archeological methods, techniques, and interpretations.

listingImage.altText: Cannon on a field with sunset background

title: Series: Canneries of Alaska
listingDescription: Canneries were built in response to the environment. This series is a summary of some of Alaska's canneries and the landscape features that defined where and how they developed. The overall period of significance for canneries in Alaska begins in 1878, when the first two canneries opened, and ends in 1936, when salmon production peaked. While some of these canneries no longer exist, the landscapes continue to tell of the history and importance of that period in the commercial fishing industry.

listingImage.altText: Warehouse-type buildings cluster on wooden piers along a shoreline, as seen from the water.

title: Series: World War II Aleut Relocation Camps in Southeast Alaska
listingDescription: During World War II the villagers were evacuated and relocated to six sites in Southeast Alaska, where they endured considerable hardship. This volume focuses instead on the places, using archival material and oral history to supplement onsite observation and photography at each of the six relocation camp sites.

listingImage.altText: People stand at the railing of a metal ship.

title: Series: Alaska Park Science - Volume 11 Issue 1: Volcanoes of Katmai and the Alaska Peninsula
listingDescription: This issue is all about volcanoes! Learn more about the landscape of Katmai and the Alaska Peninsula and its remarkable history.

listingImage.altText: cover of the issue featuring a river that has cut through rock with mountains behind

title: Series: Of Poetry and Nature: Longfellow's Green Rhyme and Verse
listingDescription: A prolific poet, Henry Wadsworth Longfellow often wrote about the natural world. His nature poetry, although abundant, is often overlooked in favor of his national narrative epics like "Paul Revere's Ride" and "Song of Hiawatha." This series sheds light on Longfellow's nature poetry, contextualizing his work through his academic, social, art, and literary influences.

listingImage.altText: A preserved blue butterfly in a display frame.

title: Series: Alaska Park Science - Volume 16 Issue: Science in Alaska's Arctic Parks
listingDescription: The National Park Service manages five parks that fall partially or entirely within the Arctic tundra biome. These five parks encompass 19.3 million acres of land and constitute approximately 25% of the land area managed by the National Park Service nationwide. These are undeveloped places, with free-flowing rivers and wilderness at a massive scale.

listingImage.altText: a group of muskox running across a field

title: Series: 807th Battalion History
listingDescription: From its formation until the height of the war, the 807th Engineer Aviation Battalion battled weather, time, and an unseen enemy to construct infrastructure for the war effort in the Aleutians.

listingImage.altText: A crest with an eagle and sword and text

title: Series: Alaska Park Science - Volume 14 Issue 1: Resource Management in a Changing World
listingDescription: The following pages describe new approaches to analyzing and presenting resource data to support better informed and more transparent decision making by park managers; first-hand observations of environmental and climate change across widely separated parts of Alaska. They invite our readers to consider the effects of environmental changes, readers to consider the effects of environmental changes, both recent and future.

listingImage.altText: Canoers on a river

title: Series: National Park Service Alaska Region Fire Ecology Annual Report Calendar Year 2016
listingDescription: This series offers the summary of the 2016 fire season, inventory and monitoring projects in both Denali and Wrangell-St. Elias National Parks and Preserves, the research and technology involved, and the communication of results.

listingImage.altText: Fire ecologists, wearing bright yellow-lime rain suits, monitor fire impacts in Denali.

title: Series: NPS Alaska Region Fire Ecology Annual Report for 2017
listingDescription: The Alaska Region Fire Ecology Annual Report for 2017 offers a summary of the fire season, monitoring and inventories utilized, the methods and how information and outreach was used to communicate the results for the year.

listingImage.altText: Smoke rises from the Trout Creek Fire over the Yukon River (July 2017)

title: Series: Cultural Landscapes of Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore
listingDescription: The cultural landscapes of Sleeping Bear Dunes National Lakeshore include a rural historic district, agricultural landscapes, homesteads and retreats, a light station, and a life-saving station. The documentation and care of landscape characteristics at these sites, within the natural environmental setting, helps to preserve a view of how the landscapes developed and were used over time.

listingImage.altText: A wooden barn stands beside a smaller outbuilding with a stone foundation and gabled roof

title: Series: I Cast Iron Because...
listingDescription: Saugus Iron Works National Historic Site partnered with students from Massachusetts College of Art and Design (MassArt) and Visiting Lecturer in Sculpture, Marjee-Anne Levine, to create this special online exhibition, “I Cast Iron Because…" The featured artists are members of the MassArt Iron Corps, a student-run group dedicated to the art and practice of casting iron. Each article contains unique metal sculptures, artist statements, and self-made artist video profiles.

listingImage.altText: Arrowhead with bison, tree, mountain, words National Park Service with park and series name below

title: Series: Elephant Seal Tales
listingDescription: Read stories of the elephant seal pupping season through the eyes of Point Reyes Natioinal Seashore's volunteers.

listingImage.altText: Two large male elephant seals rear up and slam their upper bodies against one another.

title: Series: Claiming Civil Rights
listingDescription: The lesson plans in this series guide students and other interested learners through conversations about how people claimed civil rights for themselves and for others. Each lesson includes an inquiry question, reading, and a choice of activities. Each lesson is designed to fit into about an hour. This series was created Katie McCarthy, NCPE intern with the Cultural Resources Office of Interpretation and Education.

listingImage.altText: Portrait of Frederick Douglass

title: Series: Civil Rights and Public Education
listingDescription: The lesson plans in this series guide students and other interested learners through conversations about school segregation and the Civil Rights struggles for desegregation. Each lesson includes an inquiry question, reading, and a choice of activities. Each lesson is designed to fit into about an hour. This series was created by Katie McCarthy, a NCPE intern with the Cultural Resources Office of Interpretation and Education.

listingImage.altText: Students sitting in a classroom

title: Series: Park Paleontology News - Vol. 13, No. 1, Spring 2021
listingDescription:
All across the park system, scientists, rangers, and interpreters are engaged in the important work of studying, protecting, and sharing our rich fossil heritage. Park Paleontology news provides a close up look at the important work of caring for these irreplaceable resources.
  • Contribute to Park Paleontology News by contacting the newsletter editor
  • Learn more about Fossils & Paleontology
  • Celebrate National Fossil Day with events across the nation

listingImage.altText: park ranger in uniform

title: Series: Preservation Matters
listingDescription: National Center for Preservation Technology and Training (NCPTT) publishes its Preservation in Practice Series to provide easily accessible guidelines for preserving cultural materials. NCPTT is the principal research, technology and training center within the National Park Service.

listingImage.altText: NCPTT Building. Brick two story gymnasium.

tags: National Center for Preservation Technology and Training

title: Series: NPS Archeology Guide: Permits for Archeological Investigation
listingDescription: This chapter of the NPS Archeology Guide provides guidance for applicants, NPS archeologists, and NPS managers about Permits for Archeological Investigations. Archeological fieldwork on parklands requires a Permit for Archeological Investigations. Activities include excavation, shovel testing, coring, pedestrian survey, underwater archeology, rock art documentation, or other types of reconnaissance. NPS archeologists, or those working under a contract or cooperative agreement, are exempt.

listingImage.altText: An NPS archeologist examines a site while police look on.

title: Series: NPS Archeology Guide: Cultural Resources and Wilderness
listingDescription: This chapter of the NPS Archeology Guide informs NPS personnel about their responsibilities to consider cultural resources when planning for wilderness management. Advance planning, cooperation, and coordination are key elements in ensuring that cultural resources are fully considered when planning and implementing wilderness management activities.

listingImage.altText: Chimney of house in snowy woods.

title: Series: NPS Archeology Guide: Cultural Resources and Fire
listingDescription: This chapter of the NPS Archeology Guide informs NPS personnel about their responsibilities and help them to integrate cultural resource management with park fire management operations. Advance planning, cooperation, and coordination are key elements in ensuring that cultural resources are fully considered when planning and implementing wildland and structural fire-related activities. Employee and public safety is the first priority in every management and fire-related activity.

listingImage.altText: A person standing in a landscape.
